explanation:
For a sound MISRA <string.h> bounds analysis of parse_dauth_params you need the following symbols and why:

- memset
  - parse_dauth_params calls memset(&userhash, 0, sizeof(userhash)) and memset(&algorithm, 0, sizeof(algorithm)). To verify these calls cannot write past the destination objects you must know the exact semantics/prototype of memset (standard) and ensure the size argument does not exceed the object size.

- struct MHD_RqDAuthParam
  - parse_dauth_params zeroes two local MHD_RqDAuthParam variables and later assigns into param->value and param->quoted. You must know the members (types and sizes) of this struct (in particular the type and layout of the .value member) to ensure that uses (memset(sizeof(obj)), assignments to .value.str/.len, and passing pointers to other routines) cannot cause out-of-bounds memory accesses.

- struct MHD_RqDAuth
  - The function stores results into fields of *pdauth (nonce, opaque, response, username, username_ext, realm, uri, qop_raw, cnonce, nc, userhash, algo3, qop). You must know the types and layouts of these fields to ensure that taking addresses (params[] = &pdauth->...) and writing into those fields (e.g., pdauth->userhash = ...) is safe and that subsequent calls which take pointers into these fields cannot trigger out-of-bounds behavior.

- struct _MHD_cstr_w_len
  - tk_names array contains pointers to this struct; the code reads tk_name->len and tk_name->str. You need its definition to verify that len and str are interpreted correctly and to ensure comparisons using tk_name->len do not cause misinterpretation that could lead to out-of-bounds memory reads.

- _MHD_S_STR_W_LEN (macro)
  - The token constants are created with this macro. Knowing how it constructs the struct (e.g., whether it produces string literals, adds a terminating NUL, computes len at compile time) is required to reason that tk_name->str/tk_name->len are consistent and safe to compare against the input buffer without risking reads past the token storage.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_
  - This helper is used to compare the input buffer (str + i) against a token (tk_name->str) using tk_name->len. If its implementation uses string.h functions (memcmp/strncmp/strlen) or otherwise reads beyond the provided length, it could violate the MISRA rule. You must examine its prototype/implementation to ensure it only accesses the buffers up to the explicit length arguments and never relies on NUL termination beyond those bounds.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n
  - Called when userhash.quoted is true to compare the quoted token value. Its implementation may call standard string functions; you must ensure it will not perform reads beyond the provided buffer pointer/length.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_
  - Called when comparing an unquoted value against a constant ("true"). As above, you must inspect its implementation to verify it does not invoke string.h functions in a way that could read past provided buffer bounds.

- mhd_assert
  - The function contains mhd_assert checks that express invariants used by the control flow and indexing (e.g., assumptions about token lengths and positions). The definition of mhd_assert (whether it is a no-op in production or can abort) affects whether some potential out-of-bounds conditions could be masked/assumed safe. For static analysis, you need to know what assertions are enforced and whether they are present at runtime.

- get_rq_dauth_algo and get_rq_dauth_qop
  - These are called at the end and accept pointers to MHD_RqDAuthParam (algorithm and &pdauth->qop_raw). While the static call graph shows they have no callees, their implementations might use string.h functions internally or read the param->value buffers. To conclude the whole routine does not violate the MISRA string handling rule you must inspect these functions for any use of memcpy/memcmp/strlen/str* on buffers derived from parse_dauth_params.

In short: include the structure/type definitions that determine object sizes/layouts and the implementations/prototypes of all helper routines (especially those that may call standard <string.h> functions) so you can confirm every call to standard string functions (memset here and any in helpers) is given a size that does not exceed the reachable object bounds and that no helper reads beyond the provided buffer lengths.
